citations.narrative:
According to the health certificate, on July 19, 2023, three female Cynomolgus macaques (Macaca fascicularis) (ID’s:
1030044, 1045860, and 1047116) were inspected by a licensed veterinarian in Houston, TX and were not delivered to the
transporter for transport to Reno, NV until August 2, 2023 – 14 days later. Nonhuman primates must be inspected and
delivered for transport, as required, within 10 days to ensure the animals are evaluated by a licensed veterinarian and are
free of any infectious disease or physical abnormality which would endanger the nonhuman primate, other animals or
endanger public health. Dealers must not deliver any nonhuman primate for transport in commerce unless accompanied
by a health certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian no more than 10 days prior to transport. The facility has since
revised their process by implementing a more robust inspection system.
Correct by: March 14, 2024
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by (date-60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection) or the
applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your
next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.78(a)(1) 
   
Health certification and identification. 
According to the health certificate, on July 19, 2023, three female Cynomolgus macaques (Macaca fascicularis) (ID’s: 
1030044, 1045860, and 1047116) were inspected by a licensed veterinarian in Houston, TX and were not delivered to the 
transporter for transport to Reno, NV until August 2, 2023 – 14 days later. Nonhuman primates must be inspected and 
delivered for transport, as required, within 10 days to ensure the animals are evaluated by a licensed veterinarian and are 
free of any infectious disease or physical abnormality which would endanger the nonhuman primate, other animals or 
endanger public health. Dealers must not deliver any nonhuman primate for transport in commerce unless accompanied 
by a health certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian no more than 10 days prior to transport. The facility has since 
revised their process by implementing a more robust inspection system.  
 
Correct by: March 14, 2024 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by (date-60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection) or the 
applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your 
next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
